title: herb Lubalin font
content:
Does anyone know what font this is or something similar to it.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [HL\_03.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/typophile.com/files/HL_03.jpg) | 79.54 KB |
author: lthe

comments.content: I don't think that one has been digitized, but I've gathered a few in this style [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontcase/genres/didone_extra_bold/).

I used to know the name of this font. Wish it was digital.

If anyone knows the name, I'd love to be reminded. Thanks

Nope. Pistilli Roman is quite different.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529im_/http:/typophile.com/files/PistilliRoman_6509.gif)

I'm not sure if it was ever a commercially available font since it was a promotional ad for Suddler & Hennessey (Lubalin was once their VP/Creative Director) and may have been one of their unique headline film fonts.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529im_/http:/typophile.com/files/herb_lubalin_116_4154.JPG)
  
The closest re-appearance of the face I found was Lubalin's "oh! ah!" letterhead design (featured in U&lc) which was actually handlettered by [Tony Di Spigna](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Tony%20Di%20Spigna).

The digital version of this font is now available it's called Eloquent Pro.

[http://marketplace.veer.com/font/Eloquent-Pro-Complete-JBT0001065#](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/marketplace.veer.com/font/Eloquent-Pro-Complete-JBT0001065# "http://marketplace.veer.com/font/Eloquent-Pro-Complete-JBT0001065#")

[Eloquent](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/fontsinuse.com/typefaces/7422/eloquent) is a a revival of [Pistilli Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/fontsinuse.com/typefaces/7640/pistilli-roman), not the font shown in this image.

[Display notes](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424023529/http:/thisisdisplay.tumblr.com/post/33772000924/lets-talk-type-a-herb-lubalin-designed-trade) that this ad uses lettering by John Pistilli, which makes sense. So, not a font, but similar to the same artist’s Pistilli Roman.
